statement.tex: Is the function \[\qquad f(x) = \fx, x\in\mathbb{R}\] continuous and differentiable at $x=1$?

options.tex:
\begin{center} \begin{tabular}{NN} \toprule & \text{Value} \\ \midrule \lim_{x\to 1^-} f(x) & -1 \\ \midrule \lim_{x\to 1^+} f(x) & -1 \\ \midrule f(1) & -1 \\ \bottomrule \end{tabular} \end{center}
And hence, $f(x)$ is continuous at $x = 1$
\[ \qquad \lim_{x\to 1^-} f'(x) \neq \lim_{x\to 1^+} f'(x) \] Hence $f(x)$ is \underline{not} differentiable at $x=1$
\[ \qquad \lim_{x\to 1^-} f'(x) = \lim_{x\to 1^+} f'(x) \] Hence $f(x)$ is differentiable at $x=1$
